The member of the Tribunal assigned to conduct the review shall provide the Minister and the person or ship with an opportunity that is consistent with procedural fairness and natural justice to present evidence and make representations.
The member may confirm the Minister’s decision or refer the matter back to the Minister for reconsideration.
The person or ship that requested the review may, within 30 days after the day on which a determination is made under subsection (7), appeal the determination to the Tribunal.
A person or ship that does not appear at the review hearing is not entitled to appeal a determination, unless they establish that there was sufficient reason to justify their absence.
The appeal panel of the Tribunal that is assigned to hear the appeal may dismiss the appeal or refer the matter back to the Minister for reconsideration.

Section.Text: The Governor in Council may make regulations

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: designating as a violation the contravention of

Subparagraph.Label: (i)
Subparagraph.Text: any specified provision of this Act or of the regulations, or

Subparagraph.Label: (ii)
Subparagraph.Text: any direction given under any specified provision of this Act;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: establishing a penalty, or a range of penalties, in respect of a violation, up to the maximum amount set out in subsection 46.26(4);

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: if a range of penalties is established by regulations made under paragraph (b), respecting the method of determining the amount payable as the penalty for the violation, including the criteria to be taken into account;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: setting out the total maximum amount payable for a related series or class of violations;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: respecting the circumstances under which, the criteria by which and the manner in which the amount of a penalty may be reduced in whole or in part; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: respecting persons that may request a review on behalf of a ship in relation to an alleged violation by the ship.

Subsection.Text: The owner, master or person in charge of a ship commits an offence if the ship is subject to compulsory pilotage and proceeds through a compulsory pilotage area without being under the conduct of a licensed pilot for that compulsory pilotage area or a regular member of the ship’s complement who is a pilotage certificate holder for that compulsory pilotage area.

A ship commits an offence if it is subject to compulsory pilotage and proceeds through a compulsory pilotage area without being under the conduct of a licensed pilot for that compulsory pilotage area or a regular member of the ship’s complement who is a pilotage certificate holder for that compulsory pilotage area.
Subsections (1) and (2) do not apply if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the master of the ship takes the conduct of it in accordance with subsection 38.02(1);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the relevant Authority waives compulsory pilotage; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: the ship is in Canadian waters that are contiguous with waters of the United States, the ship is under the conduct of an individual who is authorized to have the conduct of a ship by an appropriate authority of the United States and the conditions set out in the regulations are met.

Subsection.Text: Every individual who commits an offence under subsection (1) is liable on summary conviction to a fine of not more than $1,000,000 or to imprisonment for a term of not more than 18 months, or to both.
Every person, other than an individual, that commits an offence under subsection (1) is liable on summary conviction to a fine of not more than $1,000,000.
Every ship that commits an offence under subsection (2) is liable on summary conviction to a fine of not more than $1,000,000.
Every person commits an offence that contravenes

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a provision of this Act, other than section 15.3 or subsection 47(1);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a provision of the regulations;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a direction under subsection 46.12(2) or (3);

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: a direction under subsection 46.22(1); or

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: a direction under section 52.3.

Subsection.Text: Every individual who commits an offence under subsection (1) is liable on summary conviction to a fine of not more than $500,000 or to imprisonment for a term of not more than 12 months, or to both.
Every person, other than an individual, that commits an offence under subsection (1) is liable on summary conviction to a fine of not more than $500,000.

Section.Text: A person that contravenes section 15.3 commits an offence and is liable on summary conviction to a fine of not more than $10,000 for each day on which the offence is committed or continued but is not liable to imprisonment.

Subsection.Text: Every ship commits an offence that contravenes

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: subsection 52.1(2) or 52.2(5);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a provision of the regulations; or

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a direction given under paragraph 46.12(3)(b) or subsection 46.12(4).

Subsection.Text: Every ship that commits an offence under subsection (1) is liable on summary conviction to a fine of not more than $500,000.

Section.Text: An offence under section 48 or 48.11 that is committed or continued on more than one day constitutes a separate offence for each day on which it is committed or continued.

If a person is convicted of an offence under this Act, in addition to any other punishment that may be imposed under this Act, the court may, having regard to the nature of the offence and the circumstances surrounding its commission, make an order having any or all of the following effects:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: prohibiting the person from performing any act or engaging in any activity that may, in the opinion of the court, result in the continuation or repetition of the offence;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: directing the person to take any action the court considers appropriate to remedy or avoid any harm that results or may result from the commission of the offence;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: prohibiting the person from exercising the rights or privileges of a licence, pilotage certificate, waiver or exemption order under this Act for the period or at the times and places that may be specified in the order; and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: prohibiting the person from operating a ship or providing services essential to the operation of a ship for the period or at the times and places that may be specified in the order.

Subsection.Text: If a ship is charged with an offence under this Act, the summons is to be served

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: by delivering it to the authorized representative of the ship or, in the absence of an authorized representative, a person in charge of the ship; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: if service cannot reasonably be effected in the manner provided in paragraph (a), by posting the summons on any conspicuous part of the ship.

Subsection.Text: If a ship is charged with an offence under this Act, the ship may appear by counsel or representative before the court. Despite the Criminal Code, if the ship does not so appear, a court may, on proof of service of the summons, proceed to hold the trial.

Section.Text: In a prosecution of a ship for an offence under this Act, it is sufficient proof that the ship has committed the offence to establish that the act or omission that constitutes the offence was committed by a person in charge of the ship, whether or not the person has been identified.

Section.MarginalNote: Party to offence committed by ship

Subsection.Text: If a ship commits an offence under this Act and a person in charge of the ship directed, authorized, assented to, acquiesced in or participated in the commission of the offence, that person is a party to and guilty of the offence and liable on conviction to the punishment provided for the offence, whether or not the ship has been prosecuted or convicted.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Party to offence committed by corporation
Subsection.Text: If a corporation commits an offence under this Act, any director, officer or agent or mandatary of the corporation who directed, authorized, assented to, acquiesced in or participated in the commission of the offence is a party to and guilty of the offence and liable on conviction to the punishment provided for the offence, whether or not the corporation has been prosecuted or convicted.

Section.MarginalNote: Offence by employee or agent or mandatary
Section.Text: A person is liable for an offence that is committed by the person’s employee or their agent or mandatary, whether or not the employee or agent or mandatary who actually committed the offence is identified or prosecuted for the offence under this Act.
For the purposes of prosecuting a ship for contravening a direction given under this Act, a direction is deemed to have been given to the ship if

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: it is given to the authorized representative or a person in charge of the ship; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: in the case of a direction that cannot be given to any person referred to in paragraph (a) despite reasonable efforts having been made to do so, a copy of it is posted on any conspicuous part of the ship.

Subsection.Text: A person is not to be found guilty of an offence under this Act, other than in relation to a contravention of section 46.16, 46.21 or 46.25, if they establish that they exercised due diligence to prevent its commission.

A ship is not to be found guilty of an offence under this Act if the person that committed the act or omission that constitutes the offence establishes that they exercised due diligence to prevent its commission.
Proceedings by way of summary conviction under this Act may be instituted no later than two years after the day on which the Minister becomes aware of the subject matter of the proceedings.

A document that purports to have been issued by the Minister and that certifies the day on which that Minister became aware of the subject matter of the proceedings is admissible in evidence without proof of the signature or official character of the individual appearing to have signed the document and is evidence that the Minister became aware of the subject matter on that day.
If the proceedings cannot be commenced because the proposed defendant is outside Canada, the proceedings may be commenced no later than 60 days after the defendant arrives in Canada.

Section.Text: If a person or ship is charged with an offence under this Act, any court in Canada that would have had cognizance of the offence if it had been committed by a person or ship within the limits of its ordinary jurisdiction has jurisdiction to try the offence as if it had been committed there.

Subsection.Text: An individual who has reasonable grounds to believe that a person or ship has contravened or intends to contravene a provision of this Act or the regulations or a direction under this Act may notify the Minister of the particulars of the matter and may request that their identity be kept confidential with respect to the notification.
The identity of an individual to whom the Minister has provided an assurance of confidentiality may be disclosed by the Minister only in accordance with the Privacy Act.

Heading.TitleText: Regulations, Exemption Orders, Interim Orders and Directions

Subsection.Text: The Governor in Council may make regulations respecting the provision of pilotage services, including regulations

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: establishing compulsory pilotage areas;

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: respecting which ships or classes of ships are subject to compulsory pilotage;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: respecting waivers of compulsory pilotage;

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: respecting master-pilot exchanges;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: respecting the classes of licences and classes of pilotage certificates that are to be issued as well as the form and manner of their issuance;

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: respecting the qualifications that are required of an applicant for a licence or pilotage certificate, or any class of licence or pilotage certificate, for a compulsory pilotage area, including the applicant’s physical and mental fitness, degree of general and local knowledge, skill, training, experience and proficiency in one or both of the official languages of Canada;

Paragraph.Label: (g)
Paragraph.Text: respecting skill and knowledge examinations, medical examinations, apprenticeship, the provision of documents and recommendations and other means of determining whether an individual meets the qualifications required under paragraph (f);

Paragraph.Label: (h)
Paragraph.Text: respecting the conditions of a licence or pilotage certificate or the conditions of any class of licence or pilotage certificate;

Paragraph.Label: (i)
Paragraph.Text: limiting the number of licences or classes of licences that may be issued for a compulsory pilotage area;

Paragraph.Label: (j)
Paragraph.Text: respecting the information to be provided and the procedures and practices to be followed by a ship that is about to enter, leave or proceed within a compulsory pilotage area;

Paragraph.Label: (k)
Paragraph.Text: respecting the minimum number of licensed pilots or pilotage certificate holders that are required to be on board a ship at any time and which class of licence or pilotage certificate that they are required to hold;

Paragraph.Label: (l)
Paragraph.Text: respecting additional training and periodic medical examinations for licensed pilots and pilotage certificate holders;

Paragraph.Label: (m)
Paragraph.Text: respecting risk assessments;

Paragraph.Label: (n)
Paragraph.Text: respecting the development and implementation of management systems by the Authorities; and

Paragraph.Label: (o)
Paragraph.Text: respecting fees and charges to be paid in relation to the administration of this Act, including the development of regulations, and the enforcement of this Act.

Subsection.Text: With respect to Canadian waters that are contiguous with waters of the United States, the regulations may set out the conditions under which

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: an individual who is authorized to have the conduct of a ship by an appropriate authority of the United States may pilot in Canadian waters; and

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a licensed pilot or pilotage certificate holder may have the conduct of a ship in waters of the United States.

Subsection.Text: Regulations referred to in paragraph (1)(l) may distinguish between licensed pilots and between pilotage certificate holders on the basis of the class of licence or pilotage certificate they hold.

The Minister may, by order, exempt for a period of not more than three years any person or ship from the application of any provision of this Act or the regulations, subject to any conditions that the Minister considers appropriate, if the exemption would allow the undertaking of research and development, including in respect of any type of ships, technologies, systems, components or procedures and practices that may, in the Minister’s opinion, enhance marine safety or environmental protection.
Every person or ship subject to a condition of the exemption order shall comply with that condition.
The Minister shall, as soon as feasible after making an exemption order, publish a notice of it on a Government of Canada website or by any other means that the Minister considers appropriate.

The Minister may make an interim order that contains any provision that may be contained in a regulation made under this Act if the Minister believes that immediate action is required to deal with an urgent issue related to the provision of pilotage services that poses a significant risk to safety, human health or the environment.
The interim order has effect from the time that it is made but ceases to have effect on the earliest of

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: the day on which it is repealed,

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: the day on which a regulation made under this Act that has the same effect as the interim order comes into force,

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: one year after the day on which it is made or any shorter period that may be specified in it, unless it is extended by the Governor in Council, and

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: the day that is specified in the order of the Governor in Council, if the Governor in Council extends the interim order.

Subsection.Text: The Governor in Council may extend the interim order for a period of no more than two years after the end of the applicable period referred to in paragraph (2)(c).
If an interim order is extended by the Governor in Council, the Minister is not authorized to remake the interim order after it ceases to have effect.
Every person or ship subject to an interim order shall comply with it.

No person or ship may be convicted of an offence or found liable for a violation consisting of a contravention of an interim order that, at the time of the alleged contravention, had not been published in the Canada Gazette unless it is proved that, at the time of the alleged contravention, the person or ship had been notified of the interim order or reasonable steps had been taken to bring the purport of the interim order to the notice of those persons or ships likely to be affected by it.
An interim order is to be published in the Canada Gazette within 23 days after it is made.

The Minister shall ensure that a copy of each interim order is tabled in each House of Parliament within 15 days after it is made. It is to be sent to the Clerk of the House if the House is not sitting.

Section.MarginalNote: Direction to licensed pilot or pilot corporation

Subsection.Text: The Minister may, in writing, direct a licensed pilot or pilot corporation

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: to cease an activity that poses a risk to the safety of navigation, including the safety of the public and marine personnel, or to human health, property or the environment; or

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: to conduct an activity that protects the safety of navigation, including the safety of the public and marine personnel, or that protects human health, property or the environment.

Subsection.Text: The Minister is not authorized to make the direction unless the Minister is satisfied that the direction is necessary to deal with exceptional circumstances that involve a risk to the safety of navigation, including the safety of the public and marine personnel, or to human health, property or the environment.
The direction is valid for the period specified in it as long as that period ends no more than 30 days after the day on which it is made.

Section.Text: The limitation set out in paragraph 18.1(2)(a) of the Statutory Instruments Act, to the effect that a document is to be incorporated as it exists on a particular date, does not apply to any power to make regulations under this Act.
The following are not statutory instruments for the purposes of the Statutory Instruments Act:

Paragraph.Label: (a)
Paragraph.Text: a resolution made under section 33;

Paragraph.Label: (a.1)
Paragraph.Text: a direction given under subsection 46.12(2), (3) or (4);

Paragraph.Label: (b)
Paragraph.Text: a detention order made under section 46.2;

Paragraph.Label: (c)
Paragraph.Text: a direction given under subsection 46.22(1);

Paragraph.Label: (d)
Paragraph.Text: an exemption order made under section 52.1;

Paragraph.Label: (e)
Paragraph.Text: an interim order made under section 52.2; and

Paragraph.Label: (f)
Paragraph.Text: a direction given under section 52.3.

Subsection.Text: The Minister shall, 10 years after the day on which this subsection comes into force and every 10 years after that, undertake a review of the operation of this Act.
The Minister may appoint one or more persons to undertake or assist in the review.

row.entry: All Canadian waters in and around the Provinces of Nova Scotia, New Brunswick, Prince Edward Island and Newfoundland and Labrador, including the waters of Chaleur Bay in the Province of Quebec, south of Cap d’Espoir in latitude 48 degrees 25 minutes 08 seconds N., longitude 64 degrees 19 minutes 06 seconds W.

All Canadian waters in and around the Province of Quebec, north of the northern entrance to St. Lambert Lock, except the waters of Chaleur Bay, south of Cap d’Espoir in latitude 48 degrees 25 minutes 08 seconds N., longitude 64 degrees 19 minutes 06 seconds W.
All Canadian waters in the Province of Quebec, south of the northern entrance to St. Lambert Lock.
All Canadian waters in and around the Provinces of Ontario and Manitoba.
All Canadian waters in and around the Province of British Columbia.

Section.Text: Subsection 3(3.2) of the Pilotage Act, as enacted by section 227 of this Act, does not apply to the Chairperson or to any member of a Pilotage Authority on the day on which section 227 of this Act comes into force during the remainder of their term of appointment.

Regulations made by a Pilotage Authority with the approval of the Governor in Council under section 33 of the Pilotage Act, as that section read immediately before the day on which section 238 of this Act comes into force, remain in effect until the day on which pilotage charges established by the Pilotage Authority in accordance with sections 33 to 35 of the Pilotage Act, as enacted by section 238 of this Act, take effect.

Subsection.Text: Every licence or pilotage certificate issued by a Pilotage Authority under section 22 of the Pilotage Act, as it read immediately before the day on which section 242 of this Act comes into force, that was valid immediately before that day is deemed to have been issued, as applicable, by the Minister of Transport under subsection 38.1(1) or (2) of the Pilotage Act, as enacted by section 242 of this Act.

Despite subsection 38.4(1) of the Pilotage Act, as enacted by section 242 of this Act, the validity period of a licence or pilotage certificate referred to in subsection (1) ends one year after the day on which section 242 of this Act comes into force.

Section.Text: An application for a licence or pilotage certificate that is pending on the day on which section 242 of this Act comes into force is deemed to be an application under subsection 38.1(1) or (2) of the Pilotage Act, as enacted by section 242 of this Act, but the qualifications to be met by the applicant are the qualifications that were prescribed by the relevant regulations as they read immediately before the day on which section 242 of this Act comes into force.

Hearings pending before a Pilotage Authority immediately before the day on which section 242 of this Act comes into force are to be continued before the Authority in accordance with the Pilotage Act, as it read immediately before that day.
For greater certainty, starting on the day on which section 252 of this Act comes into force, fines collected under the Pilotage Act are no longer to be paid to the relevant Pilotage Authority.

Section.MarginalNote: Repeal of regulations — section 20 Pilotage Act

Subsection.Text: Beginning on the day on which section 235 of this Act comes into force, the Governor in Council may repeal regulations made under section 20 of the Pilotage Act, as that section read immediately before that day.

Subsection.MarginalNote: Repeal of regulations — section 33 Pilotage Act
Subsection.Text: Beginning on the day on which section 238 of this Act comes into force, the Governor in Council may repeal regulations made under section 33 of the Pilotage Act, as that section read immediately before that day.
